thread.title: UPDATE: Judge in Ajibade case suggests possible mistrial if jury can't reach verdicts by 5 p.m.
thread.title_full: UPDATE: Judge in Ajibade case suggests possible mistrial if jury can't reach verdicts by 5 p.m. | savannahnow.com

author: Jan Skutch
title: UPDATE: Judge in Ajibade case suggests possible mistrial if jury can't reach verdicts by 5 p.m.
text:
Photos Back | Next Mathew Ajibade Back | Next Maxine Evans Back | Next Jason Kenny Back | Next Gregory Brown Related Stories Ajibade case jurors recess Thursday night, deliberations to continue Friday Jury in Mathew Ajibade death case to get case against three defendants today 2 ex sheriff's deputies, 1 nurse indicted for involuntary manslaughter in jail death of Savannah man Mathew Ajibade Related Links The full story: Mathew Ajibade case timeline By Jan Skutch The judge in the Mathew Ajibade death case today suggested that he was considering declaring a mistrial on any counts the jury is unable to reach a verdict on by 5 p.m.
"If it gets close to 5 p.m. and they haven't reached a verdict, you know what might happen," Chatham County Superior Court Judge James F. Bass Jr. told attorneys about 2 p.m. today. "I'll probably declare a mistrial."
But Bass added it was only speculation "because I have no idea of what they're hung up on."
Jurors returned from lunch shortly before 2 p.m. They have deliberated for more than 10 hours since getting the case Thursday.
Jurors returned today at 8:30 a.m. after an overnight recess in the case. Bass sent jurors home about 6:30 p.m. Thursday, and instructed them to return at 8:30 a.m. today with fresh minds to resume deliberations. He sent the evidence to the jury at about 10:30 a.m. yesterday to begin deliberations.
Three former jail workers - former deputies Jason Kenny and Maxine Evans and Corizon contract nurse Gregory Brown - are charged in the case. Each has pleaded not guilty and remain free on bonds.
Ajibade, 21, died late Jan. 1 or early Jan. 2 while strapped in a restraint seat after an altercation with jailers.
Prosecutors contend Kenny drive stunned Ajibade, who they claimed was not resisting, four times with a Taser and that he died of a combination of events. Primary to their case is their contention that Ajibade was left unattended for an hour and a half while the defendants ignored him,then attempted to cover up their actions.
Defense attorneys contend there is no proven cause or time of death and that the defendants did not cause Ajibade’s death.
Kenny, 31, and Evans, 56, are on trial for involuntary manslaughter for causing Ajibade’s death “without any intention to do so.” The charge said that Kenny caused the death during the commission of “reckless conduct...without intention to do so by tasing (Ajibade) while he was restrained.”
Evans is charged with reckless conduct by failing to monitor Ajibade’s status.
In addition, both are charged in two separate indictments with committing perjury before the Chatham County grand jury that was hearing the case in what the state contends was part of an attempt to cover up their involvement in the death.
Bass has granted an acquittal for Brown on the involuntary manslaughter charge.
Brown, 45, remains in the case on charges of public records fraud and making a false statement to investigators.
